repnme.cdata!: Croatia - Istria Water Supply and Sewerage Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The audit downgrades the Implementation
            Completion Report's project outcome ratings, from
            satisfactory to moderately satisfactory, although it concurs
            with its likely sustainability, and modest institutional
            development impact ratings. Lessons of experience are
            suggested as follows. During implementation, it is important
            to maintain the balance between the construction of
            infrastructure, and institutional strengthening in
            accordance with priorities established in the project
            design. Notwithstanding, in extraordinary circumstances,
            such as following a major interruption in implementation,
            substantial revisions or adjustments to the project
            components may be needed. This project provides a good
            example of how new demand projections, and corresponding
            changes in project design can be called upon, under
            drastically changing conditions, through implementation of a
            careful review and appropriate revisions. In this case, it
            should have taken place around 1995 (after the war) when the
            project was re-launched for final implementation.
            Furthermore, the implementation plan for reducing
            unaccounted water, including detailed annual targets, needs
            to be specified in the project preparation documents. Had
            this plan been better designed with detailed annual targets,
            its implementation and supervision would have been less
            disrupted by the difficult wartime circumstances.

2826027.trustfund:
TF031022-CROATIA - WATER SUPPLY & SEWERAGE,TF032030-CROATIA - WATER SUPPLY AND SEWERAGE,TF039515-CROATIA - ISTRIA WATER SUPPLY
            AND SEWERAGE PROJECT

repnme.cdata!: Croatia - Istria Water Supply and Sewerage Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, though institutional
            development impacts are only modest. Lessons convey the need
            for attention in forecasting water sales during major
            macroeconomic, and structural reforms, because the
            elasticity of demand may trigger unexpected household
            consumption, and similarly, industrial restructuring will
            cause variations on the industrial, and commercial demand
            for water. And, it is re-emphasized that a successful
            program for reduction of unaccounted-for-water, requires
            strong Government commitments, well defined project design,
            providing a supportive program of action. However, greater
            progress could have been possible, had the Borrower made
            full use of the technical assistance possibilities under the
            project. While the Bank's supervision was rated
            outstanding by the Quality Assurance Group, it could have
            been further beneficial, if during supervision, the
            appropriate arrangements for monitoring progress, and
            evaluating the impacts of the sewerage components were in
            place, for sewerage was an integral part of the project,
            irrespective of the fact that such components, were not
            financed by the loan, and, it is thus suggested the Bank
            should focus on the overall objectives of the project during
            implementation. Finally, in the presence of highly qualified
            technical staff, as is the case of the Butoniga Water Works
            (BWW), the Bank should be particularly careful in supporting
            a turn-key contract, rather a separate contract design would
            have further benefited BWW, and, eliminated controversial
            delays over design, and equipment selection.
